captions.text: BuzzFeed presents
What it's like to be color blind
- I am Judy Bufarro.
- Hello, I'm Patrick.

- My name is Andrew Hater
and I am color blind.
Color blindness affects about 1 in 10 men,
and is significantly rarer in women.
- It's not that I can't see colors.
I can see most colors.
But it's that certain colors fade
into what I would call indistinct.
- The analogy I always use is that
if you have a pack of 36 colored pencils,

I can only see maybe 12 shades
of those colored pencils.
- We're trying to do those dot tests
where they have the different numbers
and it's, like, in a different color.

But trying to do these,
everyone will be like,
"Oh, it's a seven. Oh, it's a 62."

I'd be like, "There's, you're
lying, you're all lying."
Apparently, there's one with a sailboat
and I've never seen it.
- [Andrew] I play soccer.
It may affect me on the field.
Our team is purple and the other team
was a different shade of purple
and I passed to the other team two times.
- I'll often be shopping for something
and just go up to a stranger and ask them,
"Is this black or is this navy blue?

"Is this red or orange?"
That kind of thing.

- Like I can tell right here
I'm wearing a green sweater,

but if you start, like,
asking me what shade of green,
I'm the worst at it.
- [Andrew] So the stop, don't go hand

for crossing the street
and the walk time to go,
I see the hand is red and I always thought
that the man was green, just be that

that's a context clue
thing where I was like,
"Oh okay, one's red, one must be green,"

but someone told me the
man crossing the street
is white.

I like to think that I
have some sort of, like,
advantage by having a disadvantage.

- I suppose I may be
missing out on things.

I guess I don't know
what I'm missing out on.
- And it's kind of cool too
because I don't view it as very limiting,

but then when people are
just always so intrigued

by like, what is this,
like how does it even work.

Do I always see, like, black
and white, like a TV show
or is it, you know, which is not true.
- Like last night, my friend asked me.
I was like, "I'm doing this interview
"about color blindness" and he goes,

"What color's the couch?"
and it's bright red.
(laughing) It's kind of annoying

when people are like,
"Oh well, what is this?"
It's not that big of a deal.
Music: Difficult Situation
Warner / Chappell Production Music
Going blind Butter Coffee
For even more wonderful things
subscribe to BuzzFeed Blue
Subscribe
BuzzFeed Blue

title: What It's Like To Be Color Blind

comments.text:
I am color blind, 4 of my friends are color blind too, and we always have 
colors fight! So interesting that we are looking at the the same color, but 
each one sees it differently.﻿
comments.author: octopusproduction88

comments.text:
My Brother has one eye colour blind and the other one is normal. It really 
would suck to be him. because I'm going to guess everything changes from 
normal to weird.﻿
comments.author: Ellie parkes

comments.text:
I'm colorblind, I only got the first one right, the rest was just a random

comments.author: Martin Sweeney

comments.text:
I know the feel, as soon as you tell people they start an inquisition like 
"WHAT COLOR IS THIS SHIRT WHAT COLOR IS THAT DESK WHAT COLOR IS MY HAIR" 
and when I get them all right they always say "WELL THEN YOU MUST NOT BE 
COLOR BLIND" or they say "SO YOU CAN ONLY SEE IN BLACK AND WHITE?" "ARE 
SOME COLORS INVISIBLE????". I'm not a dog, I can see color, just some 
shades are hard to tell apart unless I really focus on trying to 
distinguish them, and know what color they are supposed to be already. 
Example: I might see a dark army green and see it as dark brown or I might 
think a shade of blue is purple or light light green is tan.﻿

hard!﻿

comments.text:
My best friend is Colour Blind and is the exact opposite as Andrew, he can 
see all other colours in full vibrancy, except green, he sees green as 
white. So to him, the trees are white, the grass is white. When he first 
came to my new house, my room was actually white, and when he came to visit 
months later, I had recently painted my room green and I forgot he was 
Colour Blind and asked "Anything different about my room?" He said no, I 
told him I painted it green and he looks at me with a serious face and goes 
"Bitch.." (Playing around of course) XD﻿
comments.author: Just A Fangirl With A Pencil

comments.text:
I'm color blind:( I'm telling the truth

comments.author: Dragon_Slayer

comments.text:
I began to suspect I was color deficient in the 10th grade. The teacher 
would project stuff onto the wall and tell us to copy. After copying 
EVERYTHING my classmate told me I only had to copy what was in blue. I 
blinked and realized that about a third of the text projected was a really 
dark blue-ish-black. I also noticed this happened with green.

The same year my history teacher was talking to me about my grades and told 
me that I need to copy the red part of the text book in red, blue in blue 
and black in black.

I never, in the 9 weeks leading up to then even noticed that there was 
color in the book at all (other then the illustrations) and I was so 
surprised (and kinda in denial) I got a textbook and looked at it right 
after she told me and realized sure as shit just about 4 out of every 9 
paragraphs were in color.



I've come to learn that my right eye sees more green and my left sees more 
red.

Sometimes I have trouble telling colors apart (shades I mean) and light 
blue often looks grey or white.

Just in this video I learned that the man on the cross walk thing is white. 
Always thought he was either a green or a light blue and I was upset to 
learn that actually, its like learning you've been lied to.

We take color for granted, I mean, really just stop reading after this 
sentence and take a moment to admire all the color around you in your area.

I love color very much and I think that because I am color deficient I 
appreciate color more (I just noticed the color of the "post" button and I 
really like that color, I thought it was grey) because I am noticing what 
colors I'm surrounded by and always feel like I'm discovering something 
that other people can't. It's my selfish pleasure, which is odd for me 
because I often am sickened by my disability to use words to make someone 
feel what I am feeling or to know that I am unable to share my feeling of 
discovery or awe.

However, this isn't /just/ about me, it's about something that is in my 
eyes (rods and cones I mean. The amount or lack of for that matter) that 
many people have and I was just hoping to share my perspective of color 
with you people. Those of you whom wonder what it is like to be color 
deficient and those of you whom are.


BEFORE I GO IT SHOULD BE NOTED THAT THERE ARE DIFFERENT KINDS OF 
COLOR-"BLINDNESS"

I posses some red-green color blindness.﻿

comments.author: Reed Webster

comments.text:
This is a pretty interesting subject. I mean, the color names are learned. 
The way we learn the color names also affects the way we see them. Because 
how can you say dark blue is a shade of light blue? The term "blue" is 
invented by humans. It's just one way to categorize colors. There are 
certain cultures that categorize colors differently. For example they may 
categorize colors by how dark they are. So dark colors is one category and 
light colors is another. They may have a hard time with seeing differences 
between colors that we see as obviously different (for example dark green 
and dark blue may look pretty similar to them when we see them as 
completely different colors, but light blue and a bit darker blue are the 
same color to us, but they may see a big difference between them because of 
the way they categorize colors).

But yeah, my point is, color blind people still see different shades and 
they are taught "this is blue, this is green, this is red..." They may see 
green and red as pretty similar, just like we see turquoise as close to 
green and blue. But we can still tell "this is turquoise and this is green" 
even though turquoise is "just a shade of green".

Yeah, I do realize that for example red and green look pretty similar to 
people with green-red color blindness (just like turquoise and blue or 
green look pretty similar to us). But they are still taught the way we 
categorize colors. And they are born with the color blindness, so they must 
be a lot better with recognizing subtle differences than we are (I mean, if 
you suddenly became color blind, it would be different than for somebody 
who has always been color blind).

I mean, even though green-red color blind people see red and green as 
pretty similar, they are still taught they are different colors, so I would 
guess they would still see them as different colors, because they are 
taught they are way different. What if we didn't have any way to categorize 
colors? How would we see them?﻿

comments.text:
+Game Tips Gewone Tips You don't just say it like that. For example, you 
don't just say to a girl, "YOU'RE A GIRL!" in public, you don't call a 
straight person, "YOU'RE STRAIGHT!" in public, and you ESPECIALLY don't 
call a white person, "YOU'RE WHITE!" in public. Calling out the race card 
is no good. Besides, color blind people night get offended or laugh if you 
say that they have dog eyes; you never know unless you've been around that 
particular person long enough. Also... I type too much sometimes.

colours you could see in a rainbow gradient and then they showed you how 
high your "score" was. I was in the upper 15-10% and sent the link to two

thats strange...﻿
